Name: Asterismo
Description:
Asterismo is a solo/cooperative abstract game up to 3 players, played on an hexagonal board.

63 colored (blue, yellow and red) disc-shaped pieces are randomly put on the board, forming a compact tree. A piece is "safe" if is connected to at least 2 pieces of the same color, or to at least 3 pieces. The goal for each player is to collect several pieces (in a 3 players game, 10 of a given color; in a 2 players game, 5 pieces of each color; in a solo game, 10 pieces of each color), while keeping every other piece safe.

—description from the designer

Name: Baby Face Charades
Description:
Baby face charades is the hilarious party game that inspires gut-busting laughter while putting your acting skills to the ultimate test. To play this charades-style game, you'll rely on your facial expressions and sound effects to act out clues for your team, all while looking like a big ol' Baby! On your turn, strap The puppet-baby below your chin and become the "big baby." without speaking, use the sticks attached to the baby arms to move the body, acting out clues using only the puppet-baby body, sound effects and your best facial expressions! Get your teammate to guess as many clues as you can to score points. Put your charades skills on display and get ready for big laughs with this super-funny game that's easy to learn and an absolute blast to play!

—description from the publisher

Name: Etch A Sketch: What's My Sketch? Game
Description:
The old classic becomes a new party favorite as players get 60 seconds to draw pictures that their teammates have to identify. Take a card and draw the object for others to guesS. Be prompted to draw images from over 200 cards in five different categories.

—description from the publisher

Name: Apocrypha Adventure Card Game: Godmother Promo Card
Description:
Promo Card given by Lone Shark Games when purchasing The Devil at their online store or during their Kickstarter campaign.

The Godmother is a rage gift which has a couple of uses:

     If discarded from your hand, it allows one extra die to boost your rage when confronting a gift or threat.  
     It can also be recycled if a saint within the same nexus or to your left or right loses when confronting a gift and was assisted by another saint.  In this instance the assisting saint can confront the gift and if any saint provides you food, an addition bonus die is added to the confrontation. 


Skill Keywords include

Name: Sell Yourself Short
Description:
Sell Yourself Short is the hilarious adult party game where it pays to lowball! To play, you'll underbid your friends to do ridiculous challenges. Bid to score points or to drive your opponent's price down -- whatever your strategy, leave your dignity at the door and get ready to commit some random acts of nonsense! Pull a challenge card and read it to the group, then start the bidding war. You can bid zero to 10 points on each dare, but whoever bids the lowest performs the challenge -- and gets the points! Before you perform your challenge, spin the spinner -- depending on where it lands, you could earn extra points or force another player to do the dare. Whether you're the one performing the dare or the one watching, the results are seriously funny. The first player to reach 10 points wins. So, how low will you go to reach the top? Bring laugh-out-loud fun to game nights and get-togethers with this party game for adults and teens.

—description from the publisher

Name: Apocrypha Adventure Card Game: Something Familiar Promo Card
Description: Promo Card given by Lone Shark Games when The Devil Expansion purchased from their online store. It is a Soul Gift that allows allows you to discard for an additional soul dice. In addition during the support phase, you can slot in your halo and can be used by the saint in the position define by where your card is in the halo to add 2 additional soul dice when in the assemble phase and an ally gift is to be confronted.

Name: The Awkward Family Photos Movie Line Caption Game: Vol. 2
Description:
The sequel to The Awkward Family Photos Movie Line Caption Game is here!

All the elements of an epic game night await, as players caption awkward images with comical, offbeat, dramatic and action-packed lines from hundreds of memorable movies. Many lines you’ll know and others will be new to you. The gameplay is inconceivably fun and easy…and no movie knowledge is required! Our original game debuted in early-2014 and contains 330 of the most memorable movie lines up to that point, so we turned to popular movies from 2014-2018 for the bulk of this Volume 2 edition’s movie lines and relied on some great pre-2014 movie lines to round out the content. Enjoy!

Every player is dealt eight cards featuring a movie line from one of hundreds of popular movies. One player, ‘The Critic’, picks the next Awkward Family Photos card and places the card on the table for everyone to see. All other players decide which one of their eight movie lines best captions the photo, by placing their selection facedown in the play area.  ‘The Critic’ reads each card aloud and picks the movie line that he/she thinks best captions the photo in play. The player with the winning card wins the round! First player to get 10 cards win.

—description from the publisher

Name: King of the Ring
Description:
Battle your friends in this sumo challenge! Smash your Sumos and try to land your figure in the center of the platform. The player whose Sumo is elevated up on the podium when time runs out wins and is crowned King of the Ring! Practice your strategy, speed and persistence and see if you have what it takes to be the last Sumo standing! On go roll, spin or push your Sumo into the center of the ring and be the last sumo standing to earn your spot on the elevated podium.

—description from the publisher

Name: Rock, Paper, Scissors, Pickles
Description:
This childhood classic just got a tangy twist!

It’s classic rock-paper-scissors play, but in this game, the pickle trumps all. Win the most cards to take the crown – you’re kind of a big dill!
Put the super-cute Rock, Paper Scissors, Pickles wooden pieces in the center of the table then deal the cards evenly to each player.  The deck of cards has rock, paper, scissors, and pickle cards in it, and background colors are either orange, green, purple, or pink.  Everyone keeps a stack of cards in front of them and on their turn they flip a card.  If the card that’s flipped has a background color that matches any of the other cards on the table, the race is on!  Players must grab whichever item on the two matching cards wins the classic rock, paper, scissors battle.  Got a pickle in the mix?  That crunchy green cuke beats them all!

Learn in 2 minutes - if you love rock-paper-scissors, you’ll pick it up in no time!
Practice basic logic, color matching & quick reflexes
Fast playing to keep kids attention - there could be a battle at any moment

—description from the publisher

Name: Apocrypha Adventure Card Game: Skullflake Promo Card
Description:
Death Promo Card given by Lone Shark Games when The Flesh Expansion is purchased from their online store. A death is a vision of your demise. You get a death in your halo when you fade from the mission and can no longer use that slot for fragments. If all nine of your slots are filled with deaths, your saint is dead forever.

—description from the publisher

Name: Apocrypha Adventure Card Game: Allusion Promo Card
Description: Promo Card given by Lone Shark Games when The Flesh Expansion is purchased from their online store. This promo is a mind gift which allows your saint to discard to gain an additional mind die.  If during the turn of the saint to your left or right is confronting while wearing something that is not clothing, you may recycle this card and give the active saint one fragment for them to slot in their halo.

Name: Tongue-Tied
Description: In turn, each player will choose a card. Each card has a subject on which the drawing player must talk about without hesitation and repetition for a full minute. To succeed earns the player the card. The player with the most card after a pre-determined number of rounds is a winner. The players must provide their own timer.

Name: Thunder Visitors
Description:
"Even though you don't see us, we are four factions soaring through the atmosphere searching for perfect thunders to record. In this game you're one of us! Your goal is to create thunder and record that beautiful sound of ephemeral energy flowing to planet earth"

Thunder Visitors is a game that can be printed on a single sheet (both a low and a full ink version are available). It can be played solo or with two or three players.

Your goal is to manage the cards in your hand and manipulate your die on the grid so you can create thunder and score points while recording it.

Players select cards and compare cards simultaneously to determine which actions they can play. By combining 4 different elements depicted on their cards, they create thunder which they can record.

Thunder Visitors combines a puzzle (pattern building) with simultaneous action selection (bidding for actions and playing order), that also works well when played solo.

—description from the designer

Name: Middle-Earth Strategy Battle Game: Scouring of the Shire
Description:
Saruman the White, in his rage, decimated the idyllic lands of the Shire in a cruel campaign against a peaceful people. This war became known as the Scouring of the Shire, and it showed Middle-earth once again that Hobbits rise to the occasion when called to fight for what matters most.

With this expansion for the Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game, you can play through a narrative campaign to represent the battles fought during the Scouring of the Shire. You'll learn about the rich history of the Hobbits, from the founding of the Shire to their deep links with Gandalf the Grey. The book also contains rules and background information to let you field full armies of Hobbits, including two Legendary Legions!

This 80-page hardback book includes:

     A full history of the Shire, including a timeline of major battles and key events
     16 Narrative Play scenarios, each including background, board layouts, objectives, rules and more
     An in-depth look at Hobbit armies, with tactics and army lists for The Shire and Sharkey’s Rogues
     2 standalone Legendary Legion army lists – Defenders of the Shire and The Chief’s Ruffians
     New rules for using Traps in your games
     A handy guide to building a village of Hobbit-holes using the upgrade kit available on the ForgeWorld.com webstore
     Appendix with 3 additional Narrative Play scenarios representing historical battles (including rules for Golfimbul, the Orc Chieftain)


—description from the publisher

Name: Tabula Trivium
Description:
Tabula Trivium is an abstract, combinatorial two-player game. Players will take turns moving pawns and stones of their own colour. The goal is to either remove all of the opponent’s pawns or stones or to block the opponent’s pawn movement.

Players will take turns moving pawns and stones of their own colour. Each turn, you first move one of your pawns and then one of your stones.

You must start your turn with a pawn movement before you move any stone.

You must start your turn with a pawn movement before you move any stone.

If you are able to move a pawn you must move. If you can move any of your stones after you have moved a pawn you must move a stone before passing the turn.

You may only move in a straight line, no turns along the path. You move your pawns from node to node (the cross-sections on the board).

You move your pawn one or two steps.

You move your stones as far as you like and are able to along a straight line.

You may not end your movement on an occupied node (cross-section).

If a pawn or stone is adjacent to the pawn this player is about to move, the player may jump over it, capture it and remove it from play, as long as there is a place to land on the other side. This jumping to remove a game piece is considered as pawn movement of the turn. You could jump over both your own and your opponent’s pawns and stones, removing them from play.

If a player is out of stones, loses its last pawn or is unable to move any pawns at all during its own turn, this player loses the game.

—description from the designer

Name: Toonattik: The Game – Agents VS Recruits
Description:
Shout, Scribble, Scrawl, Shriek and Sculpt your way around the Toonattik to victory!
It's Anna's Agents versus Rickers' Recruits but who'll get to the spy zone or the J-Pod and crack the code to win?
Match the pairs to enter the spy zone or J-Pod and face the ultimate spy challenge!!

—description from the publisher

Name: Medieval Magic Market: Bajo La Luna Roja
Description:
This expansion contains 10 new cards to be used with the basic game. Add 6th player.

—user summary

Name: Medieval Magic Market: El Muelle de Niverath
Description: This expansion contains 10 new cards. Add 6th player.

Name: Bite Your Tongue
Description:
Players must give clues so guessers can figure out a famous person, place or thing. Trouble is, you must give the first clue holding your nose, the second clue with your tongue "tied" and the third clue with your tongue out and nose held!

—description from the publisher

Name: Earthlin's Protectors of the Planet
Description:
Earthlin's Protectors of the Planet is a "slam and move" game with an environmental protection message and an unusual mechanic to replace the usual "roll and move."

Players move along a track by slamming a stack of pogs with a slammer and moving the number of spaces shown on any pogs that flip over within a central circle on the board.  Pogs may move a player forward or back, and others may grant bonus moves or cause loss of a turn.

The first player to reach the "Clean Earthlin" at the end of the track wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Guess It, Get It, Gumballs
Description:
"A Game of Faces and Feelings"

This memory game helps kids learn about feelings. Spin the spinner and use the gumball-grabbing mirror to choose a matching color gumball. Look in the mirror and make the face you think you grabbed. Is it a happy face? A mad face? A silly face? If you guessed right, add the gumball to the scoreboard. If not, put it back in the machine for you to remember. For everyone to win, work together to collect a rainbow of gumballs before you find the stink faces!

—description from the back of the box

Name: Feel me, Feel me Not
Description:
Personal space and sexual harassment are hot topics right now.

This game seeks to take the attention away from absolute or objective definitions of what these terms should mean, and focus it on what they do mean to you and to those around you.

A Shared Story

The players get to collaboratively shape their shared reality, as abstractly or as detailed as they want. As a starting point, they use synopses of real stories, that happened to real people.

Know Thyself

“How would I react, if this happened to me? In that story, what would I do?” is what players get to answer first. Practicing introspection, and understanding themselves.

Emphasis on Empathy

Having figured themselves out, players try to understand each other. “I know what I’d do in that situation, but how would that person react if they were in my shoes?”.

Revelations !

Now that everyone has Empathy and Reaction cards, it's time for a show-down - Players' points depend on how well they guessed what others would do!

Ok, but how do I win?

You just need to collect 5 Empathy Points in everyone's color to win a 5-player match - but that also means you have to be able to empathize with everyone on the table! Good luck :)

—description from the publisher

Name: Games from the Deep, Dark Wood
Description:
Games from the Deep, Dark Wood is a big box of four family friendly games inspired by The Gruffalo. The games are simple to learn, take about 10 minutes each and, despite being for ages 4 and upward, offer a great deal of fun for all ages.

The games feature The Gruffalo, Mouse, Fox, Owl and Snake and are new and original.

'The deep, dark wood.' Race to play all of the 6 Gruffalo cards you have been given. Join terrible teeth or rocks together to make a growing path through the wood. If you can't place a card then change it for a new one. The first player to play all their cards wins.

'What's a gruffalo?' Can you be the first to complete your gruffalo? Each player has ten Gruffalo tiles and a board to place them on. Turn over a card that shows a part of a Gruffalo and try to turn one of your matching tiles over. If you find the right part then add it to your board. If you are wrong then turn it back over and leave it where it was. Whoever turns over Mouse gets to choose which part everyone is looking for.
It's surprisingly tricky to remember where the right tile is.

'His eyes are orange...' Earn Mouse tokens for scaring away the animals in this quick card game. Pick two cards or swap with another player to get the sets of three cards to scare Fox, Owl or Snake. Read out the phrases and earn a Mouse token. The first to get  five wins. 'He has knobbly knees, and turned-out toes, and a poisonous wart on the end of his nose.'

'Oh help! Oh no!' Hide five of your Mouse tokens in the wood. Flip the Gruffalo boards to make a big woodland scene. Turn over cards to find where to hide your Mouse tokens - rocks, the path, the stream and so on. Then throw your Mouse token onto the board.
If it lands in the right place leave it there - if you miss take it back. The first player to hide all five mouse tokens wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: The Drowned Earth: The Bondsmen Fraction Starter Set
Description:
There are many different kinds of mercenary, but perhaps the most feared are the bounty hunters who ask no questions: The United League of Bondsmen. 
A Bondsman may tell you he is part of a great tradition of hunting down transgressors and dangerous criminals, but the truth is quite different. Their only qualification is brutality, martial skill and a complete lack of moral qualms. Officially they are bounty hunters and thief takers. In reality more often than not they are slave-catchers, assassins and hired muscle. 
Their motto speaks for itself. For the Bondsman, cash talks, and the question “why?” is a mere formality.

—description from the publisher

Name: Lex Saxonum
Description:
Lex Saxonum is a two-player game that simulates the conquest of Saxony by Charlemagne in the last quarter of the VIIIth century. One of the players represents the Carolingians of Austrasia, Hesse, Thuringia and West Friesland, the other player controls the different Saxon tribal federations and their Danish and Frisian allies. The goal of Charlemagne is to integrate Saxony into the Carolingian domain, including through terror and exemplary massacres. 
Vae Victis game issue 147

Lex Saxonum
Complexity : 4/10
Solitaire suitability : 2/10
Game turn = one year
A unit = a few hundred men

—description from the publisher

Name: Tic Tac Tongue
Description:
Tic Tac Tongue is a battle of skill and speed between quick-licking chameleons. Numbered insect cards are placed in standees and set in a row between the players. Players don chameleon masks which feature contractible tongues which the play can activate (party blowers). Play starts when a card is flipped over from the deck to reveal a number that corresponds to the insect cards. Chameleon players face off to knock down the correct card. The chameleon that knocks down the most insects the fastest wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Scrabblers Roll & Write
Description:
In this PnP, R&W version of the Scrabblers game, you meld 1-, 2- and 3-letter fragments into words. Roll dice to randomly select positions and fragments. You have 50 chances to make 11 words from 66 available fragments.

—description from the designer

Name: Scrabblers
Description:
Scrabble Boosters (Scrabblers) are unique lasercut bigram and trigram tiles that form words. Play various new word games or enhance any Scrabble™ game. These double and triple letter tiles give you extra points for extra fun!

There are currently at least six ways to use Scrabblers tiles:

     Gridlock mode
     Flip mode
     Stackers mode
     Solitaire mode
     Boardless Crossword mode
     Scrabble addon expansion


—description from the publisher

Name: The Order of Everything
Description:
Knowledge is power in this game of lists!  Race to place five things in the correct order before the sand timer runs out!

—description from the back of the box

In The Order of Everything: The Game Where Being Out of Order is Not an Option players are given a list of five things that must be put in order on a card (for example: Place these things in order of approximate water percentage: Earth's Surface, Human Body, Cucumber, Human Brain, Sun).

By the time the sand timer runs out, the player or team must place the items in correct order.  The game ends when one person or team completes a pre-agreed number of lists correctly.

Name: HINT Junior
Description:
A children's (and family) version of HINT - make sounds, draw, speak, mime, or use "hintmojis" to get your team members to tell you the three words on your paper, but not the forbidden word.

—user summary

Name: Salty Dogs
Description:
From the mighty Simon Bisley and Berserker Arts, Salty Dogs is a devious 2-4 player "take that" style card game for ages 8+, consisting of 90+ superbly drawn cards and 4 play mats. 
A great, easy to pick up, gateway game that is guaranteed to spice up any tabletop night.
Man your animal pirate crew with such greats as Elon Tusk, Hugh Jackelman , Arnold Barbirdian, Abraham Inkoln and Duck Norris.  Keep a watchful eye out for illnesses, like the  Black Spot and Scurvy. Force your enemies to Walk the Plank, take part in a Mutiny or sneak a pesky Stowaway onto your enemies poop deck. Defend your crew with some mouse Earplugs or a Rubber Dinghy and whatever you do, always be in fear of the mighty unstoppable Kraken!!

—description from the publisher

Name: Build, Piggy, Build!
Description:
The big bad wolf wants nothing more than to blow houses down and eat piggies up, but try as he might, he can’t blow down houses made of brick. Be the first to build a sturdy house and win the game!

Build, Piggy, Build! is a family-weight game with two components: a custom six-sided die and a deck of 48 cards. Players take turns rolling the die to determine whether or not (and how many) cards can be drawn from the face-down draw pile or the face-up discard pile. Standard cards depict a one of four parts of a house (of which there are five different constructions). The winning five card hand is comprised of one of each of the parts of a house (all the same color) + one "piggy" card.

Special cards are included to influence gameplay. The "piggy nose" card allows a player to root through the discard pile for a particular card instead of rolling. The "wolf" card can be used to force any player to discard any one card. The "huff-and-puff" card can be used to force an immediate re-roll of the die.

—description from the publisher

Name: Vudù: Mostri vs Alieni
Description:
Scary Monsters from the most famous horror movies and ruthless Aliens seeking domination of the Earth are ready to battle!

In Monsters vs Aliens you will find two new wizardry schools: the Monsters spells with unlimited sequels and the dominant Aliens spells.

—description from the publisher

Name: Awesome Little Green Men
Description:
This is both a collectible vinyl miniatures series and physical manipulation wargame. Each player builds his army (Green or Blue) based on a points limits, with each figures' points value based on the unit's rarity and value to the game. Each players' "Prized Possession" is placed on the gaming area, this represents the enemy's objective in the battle, traditionally this is a bowl of Kale (for the Blue player) and a bowl of Cheeseballs (for the Green player). Players then take turns placing their figures, with no figure being more than 2" forward of the protected objective. Obstacles are then placed and the game can begin. Each player has a total of for actions per turn, with the first player taking all 4 actions, then the 2nd player goes. Actions consist of Marching and Shooting. To March the player places a move token next to the figure intended to move and flicks the token forward, after that the figure is moved up to the token. Shooting is similar, the Shoot token is placed and flicked toward the intended enemy target. Figures are captured or wounded based on these their characteristics and the characteristics of the shooing figure. Many of the rarer figures in this game have special skills and rules. Some of the figures are: Generals, Tankers, Flyers, Snipers, Privates and Paratroopers. The physical manipulation mechanism is reminiscent of Subbuteo.

—user summary

Name: Project L: Finesse
Description:
The Finesse expansion brings extra strategic depth to Project L through an addition of goals which require each player to fulfill different conditions to get more points during the game. Completing your goals may require making compromises in your strategy or deviating from it altogether, allowing new ways to play Project L.

When you play with Finesse, you have more possible options for scoring points while keeping the same fast-paced gameplay of Project L.

—description from the publisher

Name: The Food Web
Description:
The winner of this game is the first animal to collect enough food to enable it to reach the beginning of all food webs-the SUN.

Game play consists of players being Prey and Predators animals.  Both attempting to reach the center of the board (the sun).

Rolling dice, the prey players move around the board trying to collect their three food cards by landing on the appropriate food spaces.

Predator animals, also move by rolling dice, but they collect their food card by landing on spaces where prey are located.  they then draw a predator/prey card to see if the prey was caught.  If they were, then the Predator gets to select a card from any food stack on the table and the prey goes back to its starting space. If they are not caught play resumes with both players on that space.

Once the animal has their three food cards,they can head to the sun in the center of the game board to win the game.

—user summary

Name: Mechanica: Inventions & Overlords
Description:
Spice up your Mechanica factories with devious new inventions to build around and harmless robotic overlords to cater to!

Contains
10 double-sized Invention puzzle pieces that players bid on at the start of each game and add to their factory. From the Teleporter that can move bots to anywhere in your factory, to the Nanobot Converter that destroys bots and gives you money, each invention will change the strategy and layout of your factory!

12 Overlord cards of which players are dealt 2 at the start of each game. Overlord cards are your completely trustworthy and totally not terrifying bosses at Mechanica. Each overlord wants you to build your factory in a particular way, and will give you a bonus based on how well you meet its request. At the end of the game, each player chooses one of her overlord cards to score, and discards the other.

—description from the publisher

Name: China's War 1937-41
Description:
July 7, 1937: a nighttime skirmish at the Marco Polo Bridge near Beijing erupts into an invasion and occupation of China by the Imperial Japanese Army that would not end until 1945. Western sources call it the “Second Sino-Japanese War”; in China, it is the “War of Resistance”; and in Japan, it is blandly referred to as “the China Incident.”

China’s War: 1937-1941 examines the first five years of the conflict, when China stood alone against the Japanese Empire. Each player takes the role of a Faction seeking to attack or defend the Republic of China: the aggressive Japanese, the harried Government (represented by the Nationalist party), the rebellious Chinese Communist Party, or the unruly, fractious Warlords who are obedient when convenient but have their eye on gaining state power.

Using military, political, and economic actions and exploiting various events, players build and maneuver forces to influence or control the population, extract resources, or otherwise achieve their Faction’s aims. A deck of cards regulates turn order, events, victory checks, and other processes. The rules can run non-player Factions, enabling solitaire, 2-player, or multi-player games.

—description from the publisher

Volume XIII of the COIN Series.

Name: Barrage: Kickstarter Exclusive Box
Description:
This KS exclusive Art Deco-inspired big box contains:


     Barrage: Metal Coins with embroidered, black drawstring coin pouch
     Barrage: 3D Map puzzled, magnetic, recessed (4mm thick) pieces 
     Barrage: Executive Officer Promo A

Name: Dejlige Danmark
Description:
Dejlige Danmark is a trivia game about the history of Danmark. Each of the 165 cards depicts a historical event on its front side, and has the year of the event on the back side.

There are two different gameplay modes: In the drafting mode, you try to arrange drafted cards into chronological order. The player with the fewest misplaced cards wins.

In the trivia mode, you try to guess the correct year by placing markers on the gameboard. The game is played over a fixed number of rounds, and whoever has the most points at the end wins.

—user summary

Name: Plietsch.
Description:
CLEVER AND TRICKY GAMES FOR HAMBURG

45 cards. 4 games. Easy rules and lots of fun in a small box! 
This card game is published by Hamburgs libraries network "Bücherhallen Hamburg".

The 4 games are:
"Sammelsurium": Cooperative tile placement and set collection
"Kuddelmuddel": Build loops the fastest you can...
"Humbug": Bluff and push your luck to get the points!
"Pick & Pack": Tactical card drafting game

—description from the designer

Name: The Game Charades
Description:
The game Charades, created in the 16th century France, has become one of the famous 'parlor games' known today because it involved large or small groups of people in a hilarious theatrical expression similar to pantomime.

John Hansen Co. has now elaborated on the original game to include 2000 updated names and titles for adults (ages 18-80)! The Game Charades will entertain you because laughter, like the common cold, is catching. Have Fun!

—description from the publisher

Name: The Ultimate Quiz Master
Description:
It's time to put your thinking caps on with this tricky test of trivia! Complete with 500 questions on everything from movies and music to culture and history. Use Joker cards for double points and go head to head with your friends and family to see who will walk away as the ultimate Quiz Master!

—description from the publisher

Name: Imperial Settlers: Empires of the North – Japanese Islands
Description: Imperial Settlers: Empires of the North – Japanese Islands expands the Imperial Settlers: Empires of the North with two new decks and additional island cards, with the Japanese faction connecting the world of Empires of the North with the Imperial Settlers base game.

Name: Knuknfutz
Description:
One fabulous, fun and fantastic weekend Knuknfutz was founded by feisty female fossils! Believing in fun times with family and friends, we forged on to form a frenetic form of folly. Playing this game is just plain KNUKNFUTZ!!! Let the knuknfutz frivolty begin!

Object of the game: Try to reduce your score by trading out 1 card at a time during your play. Low score wins.

Do you have the strategy or luck to beat your opponent? Test your skills with KNUKNFUTZ!

—description from the designer

Name: Family Charades
Description:
One person acts. Everyone else guesses. Score points for acting and guessing correctly. Switch it up with Switch Charades too! Its a team game! The group acts together with just one guesser. The team that earns the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

Name: Roll Player: Cartographer Backstory Promo Card
Description: A single "Backstory" card for use in Roll Player.  This card was included in copies of Cartographers.

Name: Swiss Yatzy
Description:
Pairs, straights, a number of identical symbols, a full house or a "Swiss Yatzy" straightaway!  Score points with 5 popular Swiss motifs!
—description from the back of the box

The game differs from Yahtzee in that you have to roll the exact symbols to fulfill certain objectives.
—user summary

Name: Galactic Conquest
Description:
Galactic Conquest is a simulation of a galaxy where young civilizations are beginning to explore the void of space and expand their scientific knowledge. The game is designed to give the player the maximum amount of flexibility in almost every section, so that the player can fully use his imagination . . .

The judge's manual is a guide for the player chosen to be the judge. All the values listed may be changed, they are merely given as a recommended point of reference . . .

The object of the game is: For each player and his allies, if any, to gain mastery of the galaxy, or a predominant portion thereof. This however can be altered by the judge, considering the type of campaign desired.

—description from the publisher

The game consists of two digest-sized books: a 12-page Referee's Manual (blue cover) and a 28-page Player's Manual (yellow cover).

The Referee's Manual begins with rules for creating the referee's hex map of the galaxy. The map is randomly populated with solar systems and gas clouds. In addition to the player-controlled solar systems, which are all inhabited by technologically advanced "spacegoing" civilizations, non-player systems are generated by the referee. These non-player systems vary by industrial level, military resistance, and spaceflight capabilities (if any). Spacegoing non-player systems have randomly determined race and culture characteristics which serve to impact the War Roll (a die-roll determination of whether a meeting between opposing spacegoing forces is peaceful or results in conflict). The War Roll is also impacted by the government types of the involved civilizations. Finally, the Referee's Manual includes rules for research and technology that allow solar systems to advance and develop more powerful weaponry and spacecraft, including improvements in spacecraft propulsion ranging from sublight to hyperlight speeds.

The Player's Manual explains the various planet types, the process for planetary industrialization, and the planetary installations that players can construct. The details of spaceship construction and associated costs are set forth for the game's two general classes of vessels: warships and merchants. Three classes of troops are available to the players: combat troops, engineers, and android troops (also referred to in the rules as robot troops). The Player's Manual includes the game's rules for movement and combat. These rules cover both tactical space battles (with distinctions for sublight and hyperlight vessels) and man-to-man land battles. Both types of battles rely on tabletop-miniatures-style rules, with movement being simultaneous based on written orders. The game also allows for "strategic combat" on the galaxy map in the form of minefields laid in space.

In addition to the rules booklets, the game requires hex sheets, paper/notebooks, pencils, two to four 20-sided dice, one (?) 10-sided die, and an unspecified number of six-sided dice.

—user summary

Name: Surrounded!: With a Shotgun
Description:
In Surrounded! With a Shotgun you and up to three friends are holed up in an isolated building surrounded on all sides by vicious hoodlums intent on your demise.

Fortunately, you are well armed and know they are coming. However, if they get to the building faster than you can take them out, you will be overrun. Can you survive being Surrounded! With a Shotgun?

Players win by either surviving a 25 card deck or by eliminating all hoodlums. Each round a card is drawn to indicate where new hoodlums enter the game, and where they will advance. Then each player gets to take a number of actions indicated on the card. These actions will usually be to shoot at hoodlums, but you could also move or build barricades.

1 to 4 players with custom boards for each player count.

—description from the designer

Name: ego GOLD
Description:
A Jubilee version of Ego with an assortment of questions and dilemmas. Roll the die to determing which question to get, and secretly answer the question using the answer tokens. Everybody else will now bet one or two chits on their ability to guess your answer.

—user summary

Name: Green EGO
Description:
EGO, but with the questions being more personal, about the active player. Integrates well with original EGO and the other variants.

—user summary

Name: Ardennes 1940
Description: Game covers first days of the German 1940 offensive through Ardennes. Along with historical scenario, there are two hypothetical scenarios, with biggest allied forces.
Families: Series: Wielkie Bitwy 1939-45 (Dragon / Taktyka i Strategia)

Name: Den Store Danmarksquiz
Description:
A trivia game about Denmark. You decide if you want few or many choices, or no choices, getting more points for harder options.

—user summary

Name: Tiny Towns: Fortune
Description:
The smaller creatures of the forest have created a civilization free of predators, and they look to you as mayor to guide their growing and thriving town. However, the area is small, and resources are scarce. The clever use of limited resources will determine the most successful tiny town.

In the expansion Tiny Towns: Fortune, the creatures of the forest have found a way to trick each other into thinking shiny bits of metal have arbitrary value. It's very useful — so much so that you can use this thing called "money" to get other creatures to give you almost anything in return for the right number of shiny bits. If only earning money weren't so difficult!

—description from the publisher

Name: Jibbergiggle
Description:
Jibbergiggle is a party game that takes everyday scenarios and challenges you to act them out using only ridiculous nonsense words and your own expressive face.

Can you calm down a bear using only the words 'wimmy wozzle' or propose to your partner by saying 'patootie'? Master the art of spouting nonsense in silly noises, as others attempt to guess what exactly it is you're trying to do!

—description from the publisher

Name: The Lost Realms Fantasy: Darkness Befallen
Description:
The Lost Realms Fantasy: Darkness Befallen (also known as LORE:DARKEN) is a resource management, role playing game, taking place in the world of the Lost Realms, a world of skillful heroes, dark creatures, turmoil and magic. It is a collaborative game, allowing 1 to 4 players to collaborate and save the land from earth-shattering menaces and perils.

The estimated game time is 2-4 hours (depending on the number of players). Usually, the first run of the game takes about double the estimated time, for the players to go through the rules and understand the basics of the game. The suggested age span for players is 13-100 years old.

The player characters make their living in the game by undertaking quests, each of which offer rewards and opportunities, but under a constant threat of injury, depression and loss of incentive. Throughout their quests they gather resources and wealth, improve in Skills and Items, increase their reputation, gain Companions. On the other hand, each of their failures brings enemies and perils they will need to face before the end. Between quests the characters rest, recover and use their resources to better prepare for the following, bigger challenges. Alas, all they do bring them closer to facing the final challenge, also known as The Battle of Fate. The Battle of Fate is made against an unknown enemy, named the Enemy of Fate. Characters who succeed in the Battle of Fate, are named Champions of Fate. All others are forgotten, as bitter failures of history.

—description from the designer

Name: 1 Minute Debates
Description:
You are challenged to find a witty answer to a question while trying to satisfy various conditions.
Sure, it`s easy enough to come up with an answer to a question such as «How do you survive on a desert island?». But what if you have only 1 minute and can use three words only, as many “O’s” as possible and at least one name of a food?

—description from the publisher

Name: Koldun
Description:
In a dark forests of Eastern Europe the Slavic tribes worship the old gods.
These gods can be benevolent and kind, but it takes a lot of effort to sway them to your side.
You and your rival magi will try to foresee the future of your people. Will there be a glorious war? Will peace be bestowed upon your tribe? Or will a plague break about?
The craft of the magi is the one full of doubleguessing: your rivals actions should be taken into account.
Make a correct prediction and plenty of goods will be yours. Get enough goods to win the gods to your side.
Fail and you will be left at a mercy of demons that can even defeat the most powerful gods...

—description from the publisher

Name: Werewolf: A Party Game for Devious People
Description:
Werewolf is a party game of lies, deceit, & accusations. 
Are you devious enough?
20 Villager Cards, 10 Werewolf Cards, 8 Wild Cards, 2 Seer Cards, 2 Doctor Cards, 2 Moderator Cards, 2 Village Drunk Cards, 2 Witch Cards, 2 Alpha Werewolf Cards
Play with up to 35 people (or two 20 person games!)
Most well-designed Werewolf game that exists.

—description from the publisher

Name: Pizza Connection The Card Game
Description:
Play your cards and bake the best pizzas in town!
Points are earned by baking pizzas with ingredients from your hand. Who will be the best baker, who will bake the Super Pizza?

Several pizza cards are open, depending on number of players. Small pizzas worth 5 points, medium worth 10 and large worth 20 points.
Each player holds 5 cards, drawing another at the start of their turn, which could either be ingredients to bake a pizza (collect it if you have the required ingredients) or event cards that must be played to remove them from a player's hand to make room for ingredients.

A player may also discard 3 ingredients to open an event card. After an event a player cannot fill up their hand or play event cards.

If there are no more pizza cards of a single size left, 5 ingredients will be flipped over to create the super pizza.
Once only one pizza type cards are left, or the super pizza has been baked, the game ends, and players count points.

Name: Epic Card Game: Lost Tribe – Good
Description:
The Lost Tribe is a set of four 15 card packs, one for each alignment (Evil, Good, Sage and Wild). Combine any two packs to create a 30 card, two-color deck and you are ready to play!

—description from the publisher

Name: Epic Card Game: Lost Tribe – Sage
Description:
The Lost Tribe is a set of four 15 card packs, one for each alignment (Evil, Good, Sage and Wild). Combine any two packs to create a 30 card, two-color deck and you are ready to play!

—description from the publisher

Name: Epic Card Game: Lost Tribe – Evil
Description:
The Lost Tribe is a set of four 15 card packs, one for each alignment (Evil, Good, Sage and Wild). Combine any two packs to create a 30 card, two-color deck and you are ready to play!

—description from the publisher

Name: Epic Card Game: Lost Tribe – Wild
Description:
The Lost Tribe is a set of four 15 card packs, one for each alignment (Evil, Good, Sage and Wild). Combine any two packs to create a 30 card, two-color deck and you are ready to play!

—description from the publisher

Name: Endarth: Covenant
Description:
Endarth:Covenant is an adventures' game, set in a medieval fantasy world, inhabited by humans together with other creatures such as elves and dwarves. This tabletop game with a heavy role-playing flavour, can be played cooperative or solo, as it does not require a game director, due to its advanced AI. Players will explore the vast Endarth kingdoms, trying their best to survive and unfold the story beneath the surface... if they can, for countless dangers lurk among its ruins and deep in its woods, and no one protects Mandora's Swamp anymore, whose defending walls have retained monsters for centuries.
Endarth:Covenant's huge and decission-driven storytelling.

Players can choose among 4 different warriors to explore, fight and solve the mystery of why they have been granted a second chance at the beginning of the game.

"Endarth: Covenant" is the first game to ever play on Dybo, the dynamic board system that recognizes classic components at the same time that enhances the gaming experience through an immersive living board and a time-saving app, leaving the player with all the action and fun.

—description from the publisher

Name: The Witches' Annual Race
Description:
A real time dexterity racing game, fun for all the family

The annual witches’ race is the single most important event of the year for the witches’ guild. As in every year, your control over your ‘Pen’ broomstick will be your main challenge against the wind, fire, and air elements of this ever changing race course. By maintaining your focus and dexterity, during the race, coping with unexpected events and with a little bit of luck, you can finish the year as the fastest and most talented witch of all.

During the game the players need to keep their markers inside the race lines while encountering events (cards) during the race and overcome them while your opponent keeps running.

Obstacles can be in a form of the complex movement of the pen on the board, a die that delays you from moving forward, and even closing your eyes to increase the difficulty.

—description from the designer

Name: Misdirection: Shades of Death
Description: The first expansion to Misdirection.  Adds 17 new Action cards 5 new Enemy cards (Necromancer, Shulk, Succubus, Goblin, and Wraith).

Name: The 3rd Heaven
Description:
A space exploration and strategy game to find utopia ... the 3rd Heaven.

Amid a dystopian future, disease, corruption, and misery still exist. Four unique characters search for a utopia that will renew the human spirit and set things right for all future peoples.

The 3rd Heaven is a space exploration game where players make strategic choices to upgrade their spaceships with technology that will enable them to find the sacred 3rd Heaven.

For 2-4 players. Games run approximately 45-60 minutes.

Variable player powers, Exploration, Race, Action selection, Modular board, Deck building, Dice rolling, and worker placement.

—description from the designer

Name: Raid on Taihoku: Epic Collection
Description:
This board game is dedicated to the people of Taiwan and those who care about Taiwan.

In the closing stages of World War II, when Taiwan was still a Japanese colony, more than one hundred U.S. B-24 bombers launched an air raid on Taihoku (Taipei). Political and military facilities were the main targets, but civilians were also affected. Many homes were destroyed, and a large number of people were killed or wounded.

Raid on Taihoku Epic Collection takes you back to two Taiwan cities "Taihoku and Keelung" in 1945. In reloaded version, players will have two maps to assemble including Taihoku and Keelung during playing. 
In the midst of war, you must cooperate to survive. You will be fettered and will face difficult choices. We must live until the war is over. To win or to die?

Name: AquaSphere: Erweiterung
Description: A mini-expansion for AquaSphere consisting of 26 event cards. The event cards give players alternatives to the regular actions that are executed by their programmed bots.

Name: Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Vez'nan vs. Moloch
Description: Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Vez'nan vs. Moloch contains a new hero, a new boss and six horde cards as well as four new scenarios for Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time.

Name: Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Spider Goddess Expansion
Description:
Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Spider Goddess Expansion contains two new characters, two new bosses, several tiles and decks as well as four new scenarios for "Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time". It also contains cards to make the new enemies compatible with Portal Horde mode.

It contains content unlocked during the Kickstarter campaign of the base game.

Name: Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Sir Gerald Lightseeker vs. J.T.
Description: Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time – Sir Gerald Lightseeker vs. J.T. contains a new hero, a new boss and six horde cards as well as four new scenarios for Kingdom Rush: Rift in Time.

Name: Sleeping Gods: Dungeons
Description:
Sleeping Gods: Dungeons adds six dungeons to Sleeping Gods. Each dungeon includes a map and stories. In a dungeon, gameplay will be slightly altered from the regular game.

Each map is printed on thick card stock (Letter-sized, 8.5×11 inches). A separate dungeon booklet contains all of the descriptions, encounters, and puzzles that you'll experience as you explore.

You can access these dungeons at specific locations in the atlas of the Sleeping Gods base game. When you reach a location that contains a dungeon, you can choose to read from the standard storybook, or instead explore the dungeon that is located there. The specified location number is listed in the top left corner of the dungeon map.

Each dungeon holds dangerous traps, vicious monsters, and treasure that you can find. Because dungeons take longer to explore than a standard location, there are a few small changes to game play when you enter one. While in the dungeon, players take turns taking two actions each, which include moving to new rooms, examining your surroundings, and more.

Name: Mauwi
Description:
When cats arrived in New Zealand in 1640, the Maori Spirits found this animal exceptional.
The secret of his nine lives stoked envy. Cats need to become mighty warriors to preserve it.
Attacking, defending and strengthening your ranks become the only way to win the game.

At your turn you must play a card, on different way:

     play a card on a new place (four places max.)
     reinforce a place by playing the same card or a combination to make a total of nine and create a mauw
     attack an other player with a warrior to steal a card and make a combination.
     block the column of another player with a spirit (value 0)


At the end of each turn, you must pick up a new card to always have 4 card son hand.
The game finishes when a player have three mauw in three columns/places.

Mauwi is the new version of the game Mauw with new cards as the Kiwi, the Owl or the Lizard, with new mechanics of play.

—description from the publisher

Name: Saint Seiya: Deckbuilding – Asgard Expansion
Description:
Here is the first expansion of the Saint Seiya Deck Building Game!

What's new?

     50 new cards with the V2 armors and the Asgard warriors
     New type of cards with the relics.
     New mechanics: exit effet when a car leaves the river, frozen effect who touch the cards,...
     Individual player board with the possibility to launch knight's special attacks
     and more...


A special one player mode!
You can fight against Hilda in a 24 round game in a quest for the Odin's Saphir!

—description from the publisher

Name: Epic PVP: JRPG promo
Description:
This set of 3 cards was sent to previous supporters of 'Fun to 11' games.  The cards are for use in the Epic PVP series of games but feature art from the company's new game, "The JRPG Tabletop Adventure Game."
—user summary

To use your free promo cards in an Epic PvP game, have each player shuffles (sic) 1 random promo card into their deck before set-up.

The cards are:

     JRPG: TAG Heroes
     JRPG: TAG Slime
     Fun to 11


—description from the publisher

Name: Cicera Bigia
Description:
Cicera bigia or Ciccia or even Ciccera, is a card game closely related to the more common card game of "scopa" (broom). Cicera is played mainly in the province of Brescia (northern Italy). Cicera is a traditional game, with many local variants and an unspecific origin, so there isn't a standard set of rules, but there are many local or familiar differences, though the core rules are always the same.
To be able to play this game the specific deck of cards of brescia, which consist of 52 card (and not 40, as its common in other italian decks). The available cards are king, knight, knave, 10, 9,8,7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, ace(1). It's also possible to play with a standard french/international deck (taking out the jokers).

Preparation and goal:
You play with four players (but there is also a 2 player variant), in pairs, two against two, each sitting in front of his partner. Every player has an hand of 12 cards, the remaining 4 cards are put face up on the middle of the table. The dealer is initially chosen at random, but after each hand, the dealer turn passes to the person who is at his left hand (clockwise).
The first pair that reaches 51 (sometimes 41, 31 or 21) or more points at the end of the game wins. If both pairs reach 51 in the same hand the highest score wins.

The game: 
The player to dealer's left plays first, and continue until you play all the cards in the players's hands. 
A turn consists of playing one card from their hand on the table, face-up, and clearly visible, which can take (or not take) one or more cards placed on the table itself. 
If the value of the card played matches that of a card (or a sum of cards) placed on the table, the cards on the table can be taken and put face down in front of you, to be scored at the end of the game. 
The numeric cards from 1 to 10 have a value equal to the value of the card itself and can take 1 card of the same value or more than 1 card, but the sum of these cards must have a value equal to the played card.
The faces (king, knight, knave) can take only another card of the same face. 
You can choose freely the card to play, you are also free to choose to take card(s) or not, and you can also choose which cards to take, as long as the values match.
After playing all the cards, the last player who has taken cards also takes all the cards remaining on the table.

The scoring system:
At the end of the game the players of a couple put together their own cards. 
There are 6 points that are always assigned, each to one or the other player or pair, regardless of the conduct of the game (the so-called "Honours"). 
All the other points may or may not be assigned depending on the progress of the game. 
Cards (2 points): The pair that takes more than half of the cards gets 2 points, in case of a tie (26 to 26) every pair gets one point.
Swords (1 point): The pair that takes more than half (7) of the cards of the swords gain 1 point.
Good cards (1 point for card): The 2 of swords, the knave of cups and the ten of coins are worth 1 point each.
Neapolitan(or Naples): If a couple takes the ace, two and three of swords, they get a number of points equal to the highest card of the swords captured which is present in an unbroken sequence of cards of swords: for example, if you made the following outlets: A-2-3-4-5 and 7 of swords, the score will be 5 because 5 is the highest card of the sequence uninterrupted.

You can also score points during the rounds (traditionally you keep track of this point by placing a face up card in front of you, while the card taken are normally face down):

Scopa (Broom): You realize 1 point when you leave the middle of the table empty of cards. 
Picchiata (Hit) or Surprise: You realize 1 point for Hit if you play a card of the same value just played by the previous player (and take the two cards of the same value).
Similar: It produces 1 point if the card played and taken are all of the same suit and if their number is more than 3.
Quadrille: You realize 1 point for a quadrille if you play a card that takes a group of three or more cards (not necessarily of the same suit) from the table.

—user summary

Name: アイドルマッチング (Idol Matching)
Description:
ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‰ãƒ«ãƒžãƒƒãƒãƒ³ã‚° (Idol Matching) is a Japanese card game. Players are recruiting performers to form a new idol unit.

Players scout idol candidate girls, found in various places, to form new idol units. The cards show a variety of young women with different skills and abilities. The winner is the player who formed the highest level unit among the completed units, with the level of the idle unit determined by the final combination of members.

The game is designed as a management training tool to encourage job-hunting students to understand the role of a recruiter to a business. By experiencing the recruiter perspective, the players can be better equiped to find new jobs themselves.

The game was originally published with a 40 card deck (in a pink box), but this was quickly replaced with an expanded 60 card deck (in a yellow box). Early owners of the game who presented their pink box at a game show were given the extra 20 cards for free.
user summary

Name: Le Donjon de Naheulbeuk: Le Paladin Promo Character
Description:
This promo character was distributed with "Ravage" magazine #60 (August-September 2010).
It's a new character, to add to the seven of the base game, that the player can choose to play with.

Name: Le Donjon de Naheulbeuk Promo Cards
Description:
These three promo cards are distributed by the publisher.
– Card "Chaussette" (Object) : When another hero wins a level, shout "Chaussette" ("sock") to win a level in his place.
– Card "Hors Série de Donjon Mag" (Event) : Take a Fate card.
– Card "Épée Durandil" (Weapon) : Once per fight, this card replace any letter.

"Chaussette" was first distributed with [i]Plato[/i] magazine #33 (August-September 2010).
"Hors Série de Donjon Mag" was first distributed with [i]Jeux sur un plateau[/i] magazine #70 (August 2010).

Name: Sell Outs: Traveling Salesman Edition
Description:
Think you could sell candy that was flagged by the TSA? Some very hairy skates? A lightning rod that doubles as a lunchbox? Find out in this portable and creative pitching game that will have you and your friends in fits of laughter as you try to sell inventive solutions for ridiculous problems!

—description from the back of the box

Name: Codes: The Lost Island
Description:
Codes: The Lost Island is a card game where 2-5 players reach the Lost Island seeking to find the Lost Magic Stones, hidden in treasure chests that are locked by digital codes. The first to collect 8 Magic Stones wins the game. To break a code and open a chest players need to seize digit cards the dealer flips and combine multiplication that results the code. Opening a chest doesn't guarantee them stones- they can hit pirates, ghosts, stinky rotten tomatoes or loads of other cruel surprises. The game is a strategy game where you need to predict, memorize, follow your opponents, make quick decisions and scream or sing ("Codes") your heart out!

—description from the publisher

Name: Twin It!: Édition Jeux de société – FIJ promo cards
Description: Six promo cards for Twin It!: Édition Jeux de société (Special board games edition, 2019), distributed by the publisher at the Festival international des jeux (FIJ, Cannes) in 2019.

Name: Mimetix
Description:
Mimetix is the first mime game for French expressions. Players have to mime to their team as many expressions as possible (from the 480 expressions in the box) within one minute in order to gather points. The first team to collect 50 points wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Gwaka'moli Crater Gators – Lizardmen Blood Bowl Team
Description:
If rumours are to be believed, the origins of Blood Bowl lay in Lustria, home of the ancient and powerful Slann, and their Lizardmen servants, at the very dawn of time. Though the game has moved on and evolved in the Old World, the Lustrian League is working with the NAF to bring the old and new closer together. The Gwaka'moli Crater Gators have made the leap across the world-pond to match their skills against some of the biggest names in the sport, and their natural talent and unconventional playing style have proven to be a massive hit with fans.

If you're looking for a funky and fresh new twist to the game, Lizardmen teams are where it's at. They have access to the best of both worlds: with players that are strong and tough, plus fast and agile ones. Once you get the hang of using your Saurus Blockers (not to mention Kroxigors if you really want to make an impact) to protect the nimble Skinks long enough to perform some slick plays, you'll find yourself scoring again and again. Add their unconventional aesthetic to the mix, and you've got a team that looks great, plays well and scores big.

This multipart plastic kit contains all the components you need to assemble the Gwaka'moli Crater Gators, a Lizardmen team for use in games of Blood Bowl, containing 6 Saurus Blockers, 4 Skink Runners, and 2 Chameleon Skinks, plus a roster sheet. Also includes a transfer sheet, 2 Slann-statue turn markers, egg-themed balls, and 12x 32mm Citadel round bases which feature holes to place the ball.

The rules to use Lizardmen teams in your games of Blood Bowl can be found in Spike! Journal 7.

description from publisher

Name: Complicated Board Game the Card Game: Time 2 Play
Description:
Complicated Board Game the Card Game: Time 2 Play is a stand alone expansion for Complicated Board Game the Card Game. This simple card game about playing complicated board games with your friends adds more than 50 new cards, Pieces, and introduces Solo Rules to the game.

The goal of the game is to be the first player to clear their Holdings of 5 random Piece cards. On a turn, each player has 2 Turn Points to spend which can be used to play Pieces on the Board or game mechanics from their hand (Rules, Solo Rules, Board States, Events, and Win Conditions). The player who can shape the board and rules most in their favor wins the game.

-description from designer

Name: BlindFold
Description:
The rules of this hilarious party game are simple: using a shared piece of paper, write a word, draw a shape around it, and then manipulate the paper (through folding, unfolding, flipping, and tearing) to ensure that only your words are visible during scoring. Easy, right? Now try it BLINDFOLDED! This hilarious game for 2-6 players will challenge memory, spatial reasoning, and your friends’ trustworthiness as an easy-to-learn premise becomes a complex game of tactics and surprise, as well as a chance to giggle at your friends’ and family’s mistakes—until it’s your turn to put the blindfold on!

BlindFold facebook group

Name: Flipcard
Description:
Flipcards is the perfect gamer gift, it's a beautifully illustrated postcard you can send to a friend or beloved one, but it is also a game that you can play with one to one hundred friends, just toss the postcard on the table, when it stops the game begins: any player can BID (i.e. declare) the number of FLIPS they think the postcard needs to do to REACH THE EDGE of the table.

To make ONE FLIP means to flip the postcard from one face to the other, HINGING on any one of its SIDES.
The other players can pass or make further LOWER bids.
When all players but one have passed, the WINNING BIDDER has to FLIP the postcard AS MANY TIMES OR LESS as their BID to reach the border of the table, if they succeed to do so they win the round; cut along the dotted line and give the piece cut to the winning bidder. Otherwise, the ROUND IS LOST, and the bidder has to CRUMPLE the piece of the postcard just received. Players with two crumpled pieces in front of them are ELIMINATED. After a piece has been cut from the postcard, start a new round.
The game GOES ON until the final piece has been cut from the postcard or all players but one have been ELIMINATED. The non-eliminated player with the most victory point on their non-crumpled pieces is the winner!

—description from the publisher

Name: Squadron Strike: Axanar
Description:
BASED OFF OF THE AWARD-WINNING FAN FILM “PRELUDE TO AXANAR!”

20 Years before the First Five-Year Voyage, There Was Axanar!

The dawn of a human-led, multispecies civilization was an era of exploration, of seeking out new life and new civilizations. Of boldly going where no one had gone before.

Captains like Garth, Alexander and Travis charted new worlds by the score, leading scientific and diplomatic missions to the edge of explored space. Following the examples of Magellan, Shackleton, and Lewis and Clark, they were scientists and idealists, dedicated to peaceful first contact whenever possible.

It was inevitable that they would run into a hostile power. Under the command of Kharn the Undying, the Empire saw humanity’s peaceful ambitions as a mockery of its own greatness, its constant need to expand to maintain its cultural vitality.

Unprepared for hostile first contact, the human-led explorers and their underarmed fleet soon faced their greatest peril: an invasion orchestrated by a military genius.

Four years of warfare, ending in the Battle of Axanar, shaped everything that followed.

This product requires the Squadron Strike 2e Boxed Set (ADA 1700) to play!  If you have a 1st Edition Boxed Set, or only own Attack Vector, pick up the Squadron Strike Upgrade Kit.

—description from the publisher

Name: Warlock's Eye
Description:
The baleful gaze of the dread Warlock is spreading evil throughout the realm. As your halfling hero advances towards the eventual confrontation will you persevere or succumb to the darkness?

Warlock's Eye is a roll and write game in which the Warlock's darkness grows with each roll of the d8 as the players decide whether to use the result to advance down a spiral path toward the confrontation with the Warlock or to spend precious actions crafting the magic items that might help your little hero survive the journey.

The first player to reach the Warlock's Eye and plunge the dagger into it, wins the game.

-description from designer

Name: Rondezvous
Description:
Space raced themed board game. The object of the game is for a player to move a space capsule around a circular board looking like a Gemini Space Capsule, down his entry path and to a Rondezvous point. The first player to do this is deemed the winner.
Each player has 10 capsules of one colour and can advance one capsule by one space at a turn. Players can jump and capture other players capsules either directly in front or directly left and right (similar to checkers). Players who lose all their capsules are out the game.

Moving down a players entry path the space capsule only has to reach the rendezvous point to win the game.

—user summary

Name: AR Team
Description:
A cooperative hybrid game with augmented reality. Each player chooses a character and tries to solve missions together with other players. The app shows you additional elements which are not visible on the game board.

Each character has different levels in strength, expertise, agility and intelligence. In this roleplay you interact with the virtual world by analyzing the environment, picking up items and analyzing them.

The players win by solving the current given task. Typically you will get tasks to solve mystery crime riddles. And you can solve them only if all players work together as each character has different strengths.

Name: Fist Them All
Description:
Fist Them All is a game of dexterity for 3 to 8 players that will accompany your aperitif in good humor. You must drag pawns on cards representing bottoms. But beware, nothing looks more like a bottom than another bottom and some of them belong to superheroes. If they decided to use their powers, the fist party might take on a whole new look!

—description from the publisher

Name: TURBO G.E.M.
Description:
Do you have what it takes to become a…Turbo G.E.M.? A Galactic, Expert, Miner! Climb into your spaceship and get ready to gather the most valuable resources before the other Galactic Miners. Pilot your 3D ship using your Turbo blower, watch out for passing meteorites, explore new planets and mine powerful gems! Race back to your 3D Mother-ship, exchange your gems either to upgrade your spaceship or get the most VPs.

Go into Turbo mode and become a Galactic, Expert, Miner with Turbo G.E.M!

Gameplay:

The modular game board consists of a 3D Mother-ship, 3 planets, 6 3D spaceships, gems, quests, asteroids and upgrades.

Players set up the board in any way they chose, pick up a spacecraft and place it next to the Mother-ship.

Then they grab some quests and on their turn, they get to blow their spaceship, moving it towards their goal. Their goal is to navigate their craft towards planets, mine gems and return them to the Mother-ship, completing quests.

They can also sell the gems in order to buy upgrades for their ships (which attach onto their spaceship). These include tractor beams, bigger engines, more storage space or state of the art sensors.

The space between the Mother-ship and the planets is full of asteroids that might hide power ups or danger!

The game ends when a player collects a set number of points.

—description from the publisher

Name: Redshift
Description:
Redshift is a dexterity based space battle game which mixes tactical tabletop combat with a light worker placement element.

Each player builds and takes control of a single fleet from 1 or 4 different factions. These fleets battle across the tabletop moving, shooting, and launching ordnance by flicking disks that represent their ships and weapons.

Players will need to complete missions to earn points by visiting the various locations on the board and dropping off their boarding parties. Gathering resources, building new technology, and hatching devious plots. The first player to earn 20 points wins.

Redshift captures all the tactical combat of a tabletop miniature war game using a skill based dexterity system instead of dice and adds emergent game play as players gain objectives overtime through the placement of the boarding teams and ships.

—description from the publisher

Name: Spy Code: Hackathon
Description:
A game where players must work together to decode the console.

One player acts as the hacker, or operator, who directly interacts with the top-secret console. The other players are the advisors, who must decipher the challenges on the advisor cards, then tell the hacker how to break into the different modules. The advisors can look at the cards, but not the Hackathon console. The hacker can look at the console, but not the cards.

There are eight advisor cards, and each card has a series of puzzles and brainteasers on it. The advisor cards are divided among the advisors at random. The advisors must complete the challenges on the cards, and then will get a set of instructions to read out loud to the hacker. Since the hacker cannot see the card with his or her own eyes, the hacker must rely solely on verbal instructions from the rest of the squad as to which buttons to press and which switches to turn to open the console.

The console has a timer on it, and the team must break through successfully before the alarm goes off. Players can set the timer to whatever amount of time they’d like, with a minimum of 1 minute and a maximum of 20 minutes.

If the team is able to decode all the modules successfully in the set time, the team wins.

Name: Deadly Doodles: Trick Promo Card
Description:
Promo card that was available for playing a demo or purchasing one of the 100 early release copies available at Origins 2019.

Add a Trick (worth 2 points per opponent to go through it) to Deadly Doodles.

Name: Kashmir Crisis
Description:
Kashmir Crisis is a simple card-based game for two players, on the aftermath of the February 2019 suicide bomber attack at Pulwama.

Offered for free print-and-play in the vein of "gamer-citizen journalism", it takes about 15 minutes to play. You need to print out the rules and player aid card, and optionally the player mat to help keep things organized – you also need a deck of ordinary playing cards, with one Joker.

During each game turn, players will begin by revealing the Event Card that will be in effect during that turn. Then, both players will receive a number of cards from a deck of ordinary playing cards, and play them onto Diplomatic, Information or Military Fronts (or keep them in a Reserve, for a later turn). After this, players will compare the totals of cards played to see if one player will score Victory Points on a given Front, and whether one or both players will lose cards and Victory Points. Game has a variable end point.

-description from designer
